From: "Pelletier, Adam" <apelletier@...>

All/Any,

I'm writing Entity EJB tests.  The setUp(), tearDown() create and destroy
EJBs.  Other test methods do all the - well - testing.  The problem is that
work of this sort throws tons of exceptions which I have been catching in
the methods.  However this means that JUnit doesn't catch those exceptions
and doesn't report well when they occur.

Should I catch those exceptions or should I propagate them out to Junit to
catch in this specific case?

In general how should/must one deal with this issue?

Adam Pelleter
subject: Propagating Exceptions
